results.title: Glory and fame
results.creator_credit: Ayesha Lai, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Ayesha Lai came from a big family from many different cultures. But one thing her family shared is their love for Australian Rules football. Ayesha tells of how she developed her passion for the game, through her brothers and reading about the great Indigenous footballers who played for Essendon. Eventually she threw her support behind the club, which culminated in meeting and talking with Kevin Sheedy.

results.title: Emulation of Flight of the Amazon Queen for PC
results.material_description:
me01 and ae01
Harvested on 8/05/2020 by Cynde Moya from ARC000090-1﻿ as part of ARC Play It Again II project
results.brief_description:
When Joe King arrives at a Buenos Aires hotel to fly a movie star to a photo shoot, he’s ambushed by rivals who steal his clothes to detain him. To escape, Joe disguises himself as a showgirl and sets off to save the star and stop a mad scientist taking over the world. Featuring a larrikin hero, Amazonian tribes and booby-trapped temples, you can see the influence of Indiana Jones on Flight of the Amazon Queen and likewise it features some outdated references and terminology, but John Passfield and Steven Stamatiadis’ game is emblematic of the popular 1990s point-and-click adventure genre, which often incorporated cinematic storytelling elements.

It’s inspired by games like LucasArts’ Monkey Island (1990), which use on-screen directions like ‘use’, ‘open’, ‘talk to’ and ‘pick up’ to propel the gameplay. In another daring escape – this time down a laundry chute – Joe ‘picks up’ two sheets and ‘uses’ them to create a rope, just one of the many puzzles players solve.

group.title: Flight of the Amazon Queen
group.creator_credit: Warner Interactive and Interactive Binary Illusions

results.title: Flight of the Amazon Queen for DOS
results.creator_credit: John Passfield, WarnerActive and Interactive Binary Illusions
results.material_description: CD-ROM videogame. CD-ROM, CD jewel case with insert, manual, registration card and installation guide in cardboard box
results.brief_description: Science supervillains are popular across genres, and evil Dr Ironstein from Flight of the Amazon Queen is just such a nefarious mastermind. He has a secret underground bunker with a high-tech lab where he has developed the dino-ray to create an army of dinosaur women with which he plans to rule the world.

constellations_primary.name: Gender bending larrikins
constellations_primary.description: Australia has a long history with gender creativity and drag culture, both on screen and on stage.

results.title_for_label: Flight of the Amazon Queen for DOS
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Passfield, WarnerActive and Interactive Binary Illusions
results.description:
When Joe King arrives at a Buenos Aires hotel to fly a movie star to a photo shoot, he’s ambushed by rivals who steal his clothes to detain him. To escape, Joe disguises himself as a showgirl and sets off to save the star and stop a mad scientist taking over the world.

Featuring a larrikin hero, Amazonian tribes and booby-trapped temples, you can see the influence of Indiana Jones on Flight of the Amazon Queen. Likewise, it features some outdated references and terminology, but John Passfield and Steven Stamatiadis’ game is emblematic of the popular 1990s point-and-click adventure genre, which often incorporated cinematic storytelling elements.

It’s inspired by games like LucasArts’ Monkey Island series (1990), which use on-screen directions like ‘use’, ‘open’, ‘talk to’ and ‘pick up’ to propel the gameplay. In another daring escape – this time down a laundry chute – Joe ‘picks up’ two sheets and ‘uses’ them to create a rope, just one of the many puzzles players solve.

The game has since been ported to smartphones, with the addition of improved graphics, full voice acting, multi-language support and a play through of the interactive interview mini-game with audio commentary by John Passfield, one of the game’s designers.
description_for_label:
When Joe King arrives at a Buenos Aires hotel to fly a movie star to a photo shoot, he’s ambushed by rivals who steal his clothes to detain him. To escape, Joe disguises himself as a showgirl and sets off to save the star and stop a mad scientist taking over the world.

Featuring a larrikin hero, Amazonian tribes and booby-trapped temples, you can see the influence of Indiana Jones on Flight of the Amazon Queen. Likewise, it features some outdated references and terminology, but John Passfield and Steven Stamatiadis’ game is emblematic of the popular 1990s point-and-click adventure genre, which often incorporated cinematic storytelling elements.

It’s inspired by games like LucasArts’ Monkey Island series (1990), which use on-screen directions like ‘use’, ‘open’, ‘talk to’ and ‘pick up’ to propel the gameplay. In another daring escape – this time down a laundry chute – Joe ‘picks up’ two sheets and ‘uses’ them to create a rope, just one of the many puzzles players solve.

The game has since been ported to smartphones, with the addition of improved graphics, full voice acting, multi-language support and a play through of the interactive interview mini-game with audio commentary by John Passfield, one of the game’s designers.

results.title: From fear to success
results.creator_credit: Phillip Martinovski, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: When Phillip Martinovski had to go to Copperfield’s senior campus, he was incredibly nervous, so much so that on the first day he spent a lot of time standing outside the gates, debating whether to ‘wag’. In the end, he threw himself him and talks about his time at Copperfield College Senior School, in the hope that he can students like him overcome their fears.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Phillip Martinovski, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.description: When Phillip Martinovski had to go to Copperfield’s senior campus, he was incredibly nervous, so much so that on the first day he spent a lot of time standing outside the gates, debating whether to ‘wag’. In the end, he threw himself him and talks about his time at Copperfield College Senior School, in the hope that he can students like him overcome their fears.

In the end, he threw himself him and talks about his time at Copperfield College Senior School, in the hope that he can students like him overcome their fears.

results.title: The Islands of Torres Strait
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This Land Australia with Ted Egan”.
Torres Strait is a treacherous waterway between Cape York, the northern most tip of the Australian mainland and Papua New Guinea. The shallow strait is dotted with Islands and coral outcrops. From Possession Island at the southern extremity, Captain James Cook formally laid claim to the Australian colonies in the name of England. Later the Queensland Government moved to control the Islands of the Strait and their people. Once, the islanders currency of trade was human heads, and headhunting raids between the islands and mainland Papua New Guinea was part of life. On this journey through the islands, Ted Egan meets some old friends, sees dugout canoes being built and meets the keeper of the legendary Drums of Mer.

results.title: Complications
results.creator_credit: Brook Tesfaye, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Brook Tesfaye was born with one complicaton - his left foot was bent. Since his parents couldn’t afford surgery in Switzerland, Brook wore plastic correcting shoes for seven years, until he finally got his foot straight. He talks about the ongoing complications of the bent foot, of the pain, discomfit and subsequent complicatons on his knee and ankle, and how he has lived his life regardless. Despite the pain, Brook is determined to continue playing soccer, a passion he can never give up. He figures that’s how life is - and everyone has their complications.

results.title: Going to Nan & Pop's Farm
results.creator_credit: Candice Jones and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: Produced in partnership with Arts Access and supported by the Department of Human Services and the Deafness Foundation for the ACMI Digital Storytelling Workshop ‘Telling Tales’. Candice recounts the fond memories of visiting her grandparents’ flower farm. This story is told with animated illustrations, photographs and video footage.

results.title: Why we luv Jammo
results.creator_credit: Matt Blackwood, Jessica Scott and ACMI
results.brief_description: A diverse cross-section of the “Jammo” community tell us why they’ve chosen this particular slice of heaven to call home. The post-mistress, the erstwhile town photographer, the caravan park operator and a handful of other locals, explain how they came to live in Jamieson (located in north-eastern Victoria) and how the peace, quiet and stunning natural beauty have convinced them there is really no better place to live. The rustling of the wind in the trees, native bird calls and tinkling waterways contribute a natural soundtrack which helps evoke this unique place.

results.title: Norfolk Island: From Hell to Paradise
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This Land Australia with Ted Egan”.
Norfolk Island is an eight by six kilometre paradise set in the blue waters of the South West Pacific Ocean about 1,500 kilometres east of the Australian mainland. The island was secured by the British in 1788 just a few weeks after settlement at Sydney Cove. It was abandoned after a few years, until 1824 when it became one of the most terrible and feared penal settlements. The graveyards and chronicles testify to the brutality and terror of those awful years. The island was abandoned but eventually re-settled by descendants of the Bounty mutineers who moved there from the more isolated Pitcairn Island in 1856.

results.title: The Jewel in the Crown. V.5. a Nation Born
results.brief_description: India hovers between dream and nightmare. The British have departed India, the nation is gripped by terror and violence. Long repressed by colonial rule, the vicious feud between Muslim and Hindu now erupts into butchery, rioting and murder. Rated: M
